**M.G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 20**.proposition: This Court has continuing jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to **M.G.L. c. 208, § 28**, **M.G.L. c. 209C, § 20**, and related statutory authority governing domestic relations and modification actions.

*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398.proposition: It is well-established that **the controlling consideration in any custody determination is the best interests of the child**.
*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398.support_reasoning: The opinion directly states that in deciding custody the court’s overriding concern must be the promotion of the children’s best interests and welfare, and it quotes earlier Massachusetts precedent that the children’s welfare should be the controlling consideration. This language squarely supports the proposition that the controlling consideration in custody determinations is the best interests of the child.
*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398.relevant_excerpt: “However, in deciding issues involving custody, the overriding concern of the court must be the promotion of the best interests of the children and their general welfare. … [I]n Jenkins v. Jenkins, 304 Mass. 248, 250 (1939), [the court] added: ‘In providing for the custody of a minor child, while the feelings and wishes of the parents should not be disregarded, the happiness and the welfare of the children should be the controlling consideration.’”

*Vilakazi v. Maxie*, 371 Mass. 406 (1976.proposition: It is well-established that **the controlling consideration in any custody determination is the best interests of the child**.
*Vilakazi v. Maxie*, 371 Mass. 406 (1976.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly states that in custody determinations the controlling or governing consideration is the welfare (best interests) of the child. It quotes and reaffirms prior Massachusetts cases holding that the happiness and welfare of the child must be the controlling consideration, and applies that standard to affirm the custody order. This directly supports the cited proposition.
*Vilakazi v. Maxie*, 371 Mass. 406 (1976.relevant_excerpt: “In Hersey v. Hersey, 271 Mass. 545, 555 (1930), we stated the basic rule applicable in such cases as follows: ‘The governing principle by which the court must be guided in deciding the issues raised is the welfare of the child. That is so both as matter of law and as matter of humanity. Every public and private consideration establishes this as the dominating rule.’ We repeated that same language in Jenkins v. Jenkins, 304 Mass. 248, 250 (1939), and added: ‘…the happiness and the welfare of the child should be the controlling consideration.’”

*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).proposition: It is well-established that **the controlling consideration in any custody determination is the best interests of the child**.
*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly discusses the historical development of the custody standard and reaffirms that custody under G. L. c. 209C, § 10(a) is to be decided according to the child’s best interests. The court characterizes the “best interests of the child” as the long-standing and controlling standard for custody and visitation determinations in Massachusetts, thus directly supporting the proposition.
*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).relevant_excerpt: “Section 10 (a) gives a probate judge the power to award custody of nonmarital children ‘to the mother or the father or to them jointly ... as may be appropriate in the best interests of the child.’ … The ‘best interests’ standard appeared in our case law at least as early as 1865… It has been adhered to ever since. See, e.g., Blixt v. Blixt, 437 Mass. 649, 657 (2002) (best interests standard ‘has long been used in Massachusetts to decide issues of custody and visitation’).”

*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..proposition: A change in custody or parenting terms is appropriate where new developments pose a **risk to the children’s emotional or physical well-being**.
*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..support_reasoning: The case concerns removal rather than a generic ‘change in custody,’ but the court expressly frames the controlling standard as the children’s best interests, including the impact of developments on their emotional and physical well‑being. In describing how to decide removal, the court states that the judge must evaluate how moving or not moving will affect the child’s emotional, physical, or developmental needs, and notes that the custodial parent’s stress and unhappiness would adversely affect the children. This aligns with the idea that changes in parenting arrangements are appropriate where new developments pose risks to the children’s emotional or physical well‑being, though the opinion is more about balancing interests than about a strict “risk” trigger.
*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..relevant_excerpt:
An evaluation of the best interests of the child requires attention to whether the quality of the child’s life may be improved by the change (including any improvement flowing from an improvement in the quality of the custodial parent’s life), the possible adverse effect of the elimination or curtailment of the child’s association with the noncustodial parent, and the extent to which moving or not moving will affect the emotional, physical, or developmental needs of the child.

… The continual stress on the wife and her unhappiness if she must stay here will probably have an adverse effect on the children.

*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 (1996.proposition: A change in custody or parenting terms is appropriate where new developments pose a **risk to the children’s emotional or physical well-being**.
*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 (1996.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely recognizes that domestic violence and its impact on a child’s emotional well‑being are critical factors in custody determinations, and it remands precisely because the trial court did not adequately consider those risks in awarding custody. While the case is more about requiring explicit findings than directly ordering a change in custody, its reasoning establishes that custody arrangements must be revisited or adjusted when evidence shows a risk to the child’s emotional or physical well‑being from domestic violence. Thus it provides supporting authority for the proposition in principle.
*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 (1996.relevant_excerpt: “The Probate Court failed to consider the special risks to the child in awarding custody to a father who had committed acts of violence against the mother.… It is well documented that witnessing domestic violence, as well as being one of its victims, has a profound impact on children.… Requiring the courts to make explicit findings about the effect of the violence on the child and the appropriateness of the custody award in light of that effect will serve to keep these matters well in the foreground of the judges’ thinking.”

*Hale v. Hale*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812 (1.proposition: A party seeking modification must show a **material and substantial change in circumstances** since the original order, as provided by *Hale v. Hale*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812 (1981); *Pizzino v. Miller*, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865 (2006).
*Hale v. Hale*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812 (1.support_reasoning: Hale v. Hale is a removal/relocation case under G.L. c. 208, § 30, addressing whether a custodial parent may remove children from Massachusetts based on their best interests, including the well‑being of the custodial parent. It does not involve or articulate the standard for modifying an existing support, custody, or visitation order based on a ‘material and substantial change in circumstances.’ Accordingly, it does not support the specific modification standard stated in the proposition.
*Hale v. Hale*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812 (1.relevant_excerpt: “The words ‘upon cause shown’ in the controlling statute, G. L. c. 208, § 30, set forth in the margin, have been interpreted to permit removal if in the best interests of the child. Rubin v. Rubin, 370 Mass. 857 (1976). However, the criteria for determining such best interests have, as yet, not been established, and decisions of the trial court as to whether removal should be allowed have been upheld without much discussion.”

*Pizzino v. Miller*, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 8.proposition: A party seeking modification must show a **material and substantial change in circumstances** since the original order, as provided by *Hale v. Hale*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812 (1981); *Pizzino v. Miller*, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865 (2006).
*Pizzino v. Miller*, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 8.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly cites and applies G. L. c. 208, § 28, which requires a “material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties” for modification of a prior custody judgment. The court holds that the trial judge erred in concluding there was no such change and states that the mother’s remarriage is “plainly a material and substantial change in circumstances” occurring after the divorce. This directly affirms the legal standard described in the proposition for seeking modification.
*Pizzino v. Miller*, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 8.relevant_excerpt: “His ruling is inconsistent with G. L. c. 208, § 28, as amended through St. 1993, c. 460, § 60 (‘Upon a complaint after a divorce . . . , the court may make a judgment modifying its earlier judgment as to the care and custody of the minor children of the parties provided that the court finds that a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties has occurred and the judgment of modification is necessary in the best interests of the children’). … In the present case, the mother’s marriage is plainly a material and substantial change in circumstances….”

*Garside v. Garside*, 396 Mass. 789 (198.proposition: Massachusetts courts have held that exposure of children to domestic conflict and violence may constitute grounds for modification.
*Garside v. Garside*, 396 Mass. 789 (198.support_reasoning: The opinion in Garside v. Garside does not involve child custody, domestic relations, or modification standards at all; it concerns ownership and custody of the “Lahey memorandum” and related contract/bailment issues, plus an award of attorney’s fees. It therefore does not address whether exposure of children to domestic conflict or violence can be grounds for modification, and cannot be cited as authority for that domestic relations proposition.
*Garside v. Garside*, 396 Mass. 789 (198.relevant_excerpt: This case involves the custody and disposition of a memorandum written by Dr. Frank H. Lahey regarding the health of the late President Franklin Delano Roosevelt. It is agreed between the parties that the “Lahey memorandum” is a matter of potential historical significance. Strand contends that the memorandum was given to her by Dr. Lahey; that it is her personal property; that she delivered this document to her attorneys, Herrick & Smith, during the pendency of her employment dispute with the clinic, and that she is entitled to its return.

*Adoption of Frederick*, 405 Mass. 1 (19.proposition: Massachusetts courts have held that exposure of children to domestic conflict and violence may constitute grounds for modification.
*Adoption of Frederick*, 405 Mass. 1 (19.support_reasoning: This case concerns a petition to dispense with parental consent to adoption, not a modification of custody or visitation. The court’s analysis focuses on parental unfitness, the child’s relationship with foster parents, and procedural issues regarding issue preclusion. While it discusses deterioration of the parent–child relationship and the child’s behavioral issues, it does not involve or articulate any rule about exposure to domestic conflict or violence as a ground for modification, nor is there a modification proceeding at issue. Thus it does not support the stated proposition.
*Adoption of Frederick*, 405 Mass. 1 (19.relevant_excerpt: “In 1986, BSCA, pursuant to G.L.c. 210, § 3(b), filed a petition to dispense with parental consent to the child's adoption… The probate judge found… that the mother and the biological father were unfit to assume parental responsibilities, and that the BCSA's plan for adoption was in the best interests of the child…. In a proceeding on a petition to dispense with consent to adoption under G.L.c. 210, § 3, the focus is whether ‘the natural parents are currently fit to further the welfare and best interests of the child.’”

*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Furthermore, *Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001) and *M.G.L. c. 208, § 31A* direct the court to consider any history of abuse or risk of harm to the child’s physical or emotional health in determining custody and parenting time.
*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: Rosenthal v. Maney is a relocation and custody-modification case focused on the need for a material and substantial change in circumstances under G.L. c. 208, § 28 and application of the Yannas ‘real advantage’ standard under § 30. The opinion does not discuss G.L. c. 208, § 31A, nor does it direct trial courts to consider a history of abuse or risk of harm to the child’s physical or emotional health when determining custody or parenting time. The proposition attributes a statutory factor and abuse-related analysis to Rosenthal that is not present in the decision.
*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “Our decision today, that a request for modification of custody is distinct from a request to relocate and must be based on a material and substantial change in circumstances other than the move, is consistent with these decisions and with G. L. c. 208, § 28 (‘the court may make a judgment modifying its earlier judgment as to the care and custody of the minor children of the parties provided that the court finds that a material and substantial change in circumstances of the parties has occurred and the judgment of modification is necessary in the best interests of the children’).”

*M.G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 31A*.proposition: Furthermore, *Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001) and *M.G.L. c. 208, § 31A* direct the court to consider any history of abuse or risk of harm to the child’s physical or emotional health in determining custody and parenting time.

*Bouchard v. Bouchard*, 12 Mass. App. Ct.proposition: In accordance with *Bouchard v. Bouchard*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 899 (1981), modification is appropriate where the living situation of a custodial or non-custodial parent creates risk or instability inconsistent with the children’s best interests.
*Bouchard v. Bouchard*, 12 Mass. App. Ct.support_reasoning: The opinion focuses on the best‑interests standard generally and on the need for findings comparing the parents’ respective environments; it does not involve or decide a modification proceeding based on a change in a parent’s living situation creating risk or instability. The court remands for proper findings under G.L. c. 208, § 31 and emphasizes that custody cannot be used to punish a parent for misconduct unrelated to the child’s welfare. The claimed proposition about when modification is appropriate is not addressed or established by this case.
*Bouchard v. Bouchard*, 12 Mass. App. Ct.relevant_excerpt: “This court will not sustain a custody award unless all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child have been weighed… The weight ascribed to the respective factors is to be measured solely in terms of its effect on the welfare or well being of the child… On rehearing, the findings should examine the relative advantages of the respective parental environments… whether and in what respects that environment has been helpful or detrimental to the child’s well being.”
